Question
========
A researcher administered a questionnaire to 175 randomly selected employees of a large company a questionnaire that mapped how they rated their supervisor. The scores ranged from 1 (very negative) to 10 (very positive). It tests whether people with permanent contracts \[group 2; n=75] evaluate their supervisor differently than people with a temporary contract ______. It calculates the 95% confidence interval of the difference in averages, µ<sub>1</sub> - µ<sub>2</sub>. This interval turns out to be µ[-0.04; 0.08] are.  
  
Do the mean ratings of the two groups differ significantly from each other? And from what can this be inferred?

Answerlist
----------
* Yes, because the number 0.00 lies within the interval.
* Yes, because the number 0.05 lies within the interval.
* No, because the number 0.05 lies within the interval.
* No, because the number 0.00 lies within the interval.
